stream_context.summary: Kaze worked primarily on the overworld, refining the layout of the shipyard/final boss area and planning a melon farm. He also showcased recent progress in Course 7, specifically the addition of many new ambient sound effects. Key technical topics discussed and worked on included N64 RAM limitations, emulator compatibility, and a custom microcode (F3DX3) that solves rendering precision issues.

development_findings.summary: The team has finished 15 courses and is now in the 'final stretch,' focusing on completing the massive overworld, which is estimated to make the game four times the size of the original SM64.
Kaze added numerous ambient sound effects to Course 7 (e.g., rollercoaster, fire, character noises) to greatly enhance the level's atmosphere and feeling of life.
development_findings.quote: Just adding a couple sound effects makes it so much better.

development_findings.summary: A significant technical hurdle, persistent audio crackling, has been resolved, marking a major improvement in the game's polish.
development_findings.quote: I made the most important fix in history yesterday. The audio crackling is gone.

development_findings.summary: The project is now using a custom N64 microcode (F3DX3) developed by team member Sauraen to overcome the console's inherent fixed-point precision limitations, reducing visual artifacts.
development_findings.quote: Fortunately, just recently, we got an upgrade to F3DX3. Which is like a custom microcode that Sauraen is working on. And that has increased the precision eightfold.

development_findings.summary: The overworld is pushing the N64's 8MB RAM limit, forcing Kaze to actively manage memory by removing unused assets like a comet and UFO platform to prevent crashes.
development_findings.quote: We're out of memory in this level so let me just make up some memory by killing unused assets.

development_findings.summary: Kaze defended the design of a rollercoaster sequence over a more traditional platforming challenge, prioritizing a 'cool,' fun experience over textbook design.
development_findings.quote: What's so bad about the pokey carrying the the balls around? It just isn't fun... plus you get to ride the fucking rollercoaster, how cool is that?

development_findings.summary: Kaze expressed deep frustration with modern game engine workflows, specifically citing Unreal Engine 5's long compilation times, stating he would use his own engine for a personal project.
Kaze explains the team's approach to RAM is to use the full 8MB available on the expansion pak, as it simplifies programming even if it appears wasteful.
development_findings.quote: They're just very wasteful of RAM so it may seem that way. Well, it's not wasting if the 8MB is there anyway, right?

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a philosophy that meaningful creation involves suffering, contrasting it with mindless consumption as the only other alternative in life.
context_findings.quote: Developing video games is suffering. The Buddhists had it right when they said that life is suffering. Because what do you do if you're not suffering? Scrolling TikTok reels?

context_findings.summary: Kaze's core motivation for playing and creating games is the pursuit of unique experiences, which influences his design decisions and appreciation for other projects.
context_findings.quote: I want new experiences. In fact, unique video games is specifically what I'm seeking out when I play a video game.

context_findings.summary: Kaze mentioned he lives in Canada with his wife, Zeina, and they have a new baby. He also has a professional game programmer job under an NDA.
Kaze is exploring merchandising options for the project, indicating a level of community engagement and brand-building beyond the game itself.
context_findings.quote: I was actually in talk with a merch company today. And if you're lucky, we can organize those.

context_findings.summary: The project's scope has significantly expanded from its original concept, largely due to the addition of complex, custom features.
context_findings.quote: The initial vision for our team was a simple hack, but then it became so much bigger. I think the main reason this is taking long is because we have like character attractions and stuff.

context_findings.summary: When critiquing another fan-made game, Kaze revealed his aversion to projects that feel derivative or don't push creative boundaries, even if they are technically competent.
context_findings.quote: I have not played it, but I've seen someone play it. It looked very, like, my first Super Mario 64 hack to me.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expressed a self-aware fear of being misinterpreted while explaining his tendency to deconstruct questions to ensure he understands them correctly before answering.
context_findings.quote: My biggest fear is that people are going to accuse me of talking like Jordan Peterson. Because I also always clarify. But I do it in good faith, I promise.

biobak.summary: Kaze showed Biobak the new ambient sound effects in Course 7, actively seeking his real-time feedback on stream.
Kaze references past collaboration with Biobak on a pirate ship level, showing an iterative process where Biobak provides art assets to fit a theme.
biobak.quote: I'm not sure if Biobak completely replaced the sail texture or if you just put holes into it, but this looks a lot more pirate-y now.

badub.summary: Kaze refers to the game's music as 'Badub's music,' indicating Badub is the composer whose work is integrated into the current build.
badub.quote: Half time done enjoying my own music. Or well, Badub's music.

zeina.summary: Kaze credits 'Zeno' (likely Zeina) with creating his profile picture, indicating her artistic contributions extend to branding assets.
zeina.quote: Unless you're talking about the Yoshi with the sunglasses then that would be Zeno.

zeina.summary: Kaze ends the stream to spend personal time with his wife, Zeina, highlighting their work-life balance.
zeina.quote: I think I'm done now because me and Zeina we want to go to the beach still.

key_stories.title: The Overworld Memory Crash
key_stories.summary: While working on the overworld, Kaze encountered a persistent crash. He diagnosed it as a RAM overload issue and solved it by manually removing old, unused assets from the level, making it stable enough for himself and others to work on.
key_stories.challenge: The game was consistently crashing when trying to load the overworld map, preventing further development and testing in that area.
key_stories.process: Kaze hypothesized the crash was due to exceeding the N64's RAM limit. To test this, he identified and removed several unused assets (a comet and a UFO platform) from the level data to free up memory. After re-exporting, he loaded the level again, and it worked without crashing.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully fixed the crash, confirming it was a memory issue. He made the area accessible for other team members, like Sauraen, who needed it.
key_stories.key_quote: Hey it was a RAM issue. I need to fix this for Sauraen actually.

key_stories.title: Solving the N64 Precision Problem
key_stories.summary: To overcome the N64's inherent visual precision flaws that plague large-scale mods, team member Sauraen developed a custom microcode. Kaze integrated this 'F3DX3' into the project, increasing rendering precision by eight times and ensuring the game looks stable on real hardware.
key_stories.challenge: The N64 has known fixed-point precision issues that cause visual artifacts (z-fighting, wobbly vertices) in large levels, a problem that would affect the game's quality on original hardware.
key_stories.process: The team was using the F3DX microcode, which had poor precision. Team member Sauraen developed a custom microcode, F3DX3, that optimizes an operation to regain lost precision. Kaze implemented this, and demonstrated on stream that a level which he expected to have visual issues now looked stable on an N64 emulator.
key_stories.outcome: The team adopted a new custom microcode, F3DX3, which dramatically increases rendering precision. This solves a fundamental hardware limitation, allowing for larger and more detailed levels without the typical visual glitches on N64.
key_stories.key_quote: The precision is twice as high as it is in F3DX. But fortunately, just recently, we got an upgrade to F3DX3... that has increased the precision eightfold, if I remember correctly. Without any cost.

key_stories.title: The Forgotten Wing Cap Level
key_stories.summary: During a live review of the overworld, Kaze had a moment of panic when he realized the Wing Cap level entrance was completely missing from the plan. After checking his notes, he quickly integrated it into the world by deciding it would be found inside a hotel room in the 'Koopa with Koff' level.
key_stories.challenge: While reviewing the overworld layout, Kaze realized there was no planned entrance for the Wing Cap level, a major oversight in the game's progression.
key_stories.process: Kaze was looking at his overworld map when he noticed the absence of a Wing Cap level. He frantically searched his notes and plans. He then recalled a connection to another level, 'Koopa with Koff,' and decided on the spot that the entrance would be located in a hotel room there, solving the design problem live on stream.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze quickly devised a solution, deciding the Wing Cap will be accessible from a hotel room within the 'Koopa with Koff' level, integrating it logically into the existing world map.
key_stories.key_quote: Where the fuck is the wing cap? We indeed do not have the wing cap planned in. How did I forget about that?

open_questions.context: Kaze credits a team member named Sauraen with developing a custom N64 microcode (F3DX3) that solved major rendering precision issues. He also mentions needing to fix a bug for Sauraen.
questions: What is Sauraen's official role on the team?
Can you describe the collaboration process for developing something as technical as a new microcode?
What was the moment you realized the standard microcodes weren't going to be enough for your vision?
How does Sauraen's technical work enable or influence your creative design choices?

open_questions.topic: Navigating a Creative and Personal Partnership
open_questions.context: Kaze mentions that he and his wife, Zeina, are both working on the game, with Zeina contributing animations. He ends the stream to go to the beach with her.
questions: How do you and Zeina balance your personal relationship with your professional collaboration on a demanding project?
Can you give an example of a time when being partners helped solve a creative problem?
How do you establish boundaries between 'work time' on the hack and 'personal time' as a couple?
How has becoming parents recently impacted your development schedule and collaboration?

open_questions.topic: Project Scope Creep and Initial Vision
open_questions.context: Kaze states that the project's initial vision was much simpler, but it grew significantly due to features like 'character attractions'.
questions: What was the original, simple vision for this project?
What was the 'tipping point' where you and the team decided to dramatically expand the scope?
What exactly do you mean by 'character attractions,' and how did they contribute to the project's complexity?
Was there ever a debate about sticking to the simpler plan, or was the team unanimous about making it bigger?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions being in talks with a merchandising company.
questions: What prompted the idea of creating merchandise for a fan project?
What kind of merchandise are you considering?
Is this a way to fund development, or is it purely for the community?
How does creating a 'brand' around a ROM hack feel, especially with the legal grey area of the medium?

open_questions.context: Kaze decides the Wing Cap level will be in a hotel room in a level called 'Koopa with Koff'. The name is mentioned but the level concept isn't explained.
questions: What is the theme or story behind the 'Koopa with Koff' level?
Why was a hotel room the right fit for the Wing Cap entrance?
Can you describe the overall world map and how the different levels connect thematically?
